question.title: Controller and beans are using different contexts
question.body:
I'm learning Spring and Spring Boot and made a simple education project. This is just simple Spring Boot project without any specified configurations.

When POST request received it prints:

LoginProcessor constructor: Lums is NULL!

loginProcessor is not NULL!

loggedUserManagementService is not NULL!

java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot invoke "ep.ch9.users.logged.LoggedUserManagementService.setUsername(String)" because "this.loggedUserManagementService" is null at ep.ch9.users.LoginProcessor.login(LoginProcessor.java:33) ~[classes/:na] at ep.ch9.controllers.LoginController.loginPost(LoginController.java:44) ~[classes/:na] .....etc....

Spring injects components into controller just fine, but any other components(services, repositories) classes get beans injected as NULL. What is this problem? Is it uses another context for injecting that it can't reach?

I've tried without @Scope, but it didn't change anything. @Autowired ApplicationContext field in LoginProcessor also equals null.

answers.body: I've solved the problem. The answer above gave an idea and I've known about this thing. Actually, injecting into constructor is not RECOMMENDED but NECESSARY. When I injected LoginProcessor into LoginController's constructor instead of method's parameters, everything works as it should.

It is not recommended to inject dependencies directly into the controller method; it is better to use field, setter, or constructor-based injection. Additionally, it is not a common practice to use Session or Request scopes for the service classes.

Regarding LoginProcessor - since it's session-scoped, and the request context doesnâ€™t yet have a session, the bean is null. To make it work, it is worth adding a proxying (proxyMode = ScopedProxyMode.TARGET_CLASS) - so Spring will inject a Proxy object, which will be resolved dynamically at runtime when the object is needed.

79597927.body: Isn't the OP trying to inject a session scoped bean in the constructor of a request scoped bean?

79630115.body: It isn't necessary. The problem is your expectation that the @Autowired works in a controller method, which it doesn't. What happens is that a new instance of LoginProcessor is going to be created but that isn't a spring bean, it will just be used for binding.
